field.label: Interface
field.help: Select an interface where this settings apply to.

field.label: Area
field.help: Assigns the network to an OSPF area using an identifier like 0.0.0.0 (Backbone Area). The Backbone Area connects other areas, supporting inter-area communication, while additional areas (e.g., 0.0.0.1, 0.0.0.255) segment the network logically to limit routing updates. Only use Area in Interface tab or in Network tab once.

field.label: Passive Interface
field.help: Disables OSPF Hello packets on the interface, preventing neighbor relationships (used for security or optimization).

field.label: Cost
field.help: Sets the OSPF metric for path selection; lower costs are preferred paths within the area.

field.label: Cost (when demoted)
field.help: Specifies metric cost when interface is in backup mode via CARP, deprioritizing paths dynamically.

field.label: Depend on (carp)
field.help: Links the interface cost to a CARP VHID, adjusting costs based on primary or backup status.

field.label: Hello Interval
field.help: Sets frequency (in seconds) of Hello packets to maintain OSPF neighbor relationships.

field.label: Dead Interval
field.help: Defines the timeout period for OSPF neighbors; after this period, the neighbor is marked as down.

field.label: Retransmission Interval
field.help: Time (seconds) to wait before resending Link-State Advertisements (LSAs) if acknowledgment is delayed.

field.label: Retransmission Delay
field.help: Configures the hold time before LSAs are resent, accommodating slow or high-latency links.

field.label: Priority
field.help: Determines the likelihood of becoming a Designated Router; higher values increase priority.

field.label: BFD
field.help: Activates Bidirectional Forwarding Detection for rapid link failure detection; peer configuration required.

field.label: Network Type
field.help: Defines the OSPF network type, impacting adjacency and LSA flooding methods. "Broadcast Multi-Access": Assumes networks supporting multiple routers with broadcast capability (e.g., Ethernet). "Non-Broadcast Multi-Access (NBMA)"": For networks without broadcast support (e.g., Frame Relay); requires manual neighbor setup. "Point-to-Multipoint": Connects multiple routers over a single interface, treating each as a point-to-point link. "Point-to-Point": Directly connects two routers, simplifying adjacency and LSA transmission.
